metadata.decision_summary:
**Case Summary: Bennett Coleman & Co. Ltd. v. ARG Outlier Media Pvt Ltd.**

**Background:**
The present case is an application under Order XI Rule 5 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (CPC) as applicable to commercial suits under the Commercial Courts Act, 2015 filed by Bennett Coleman & Co. Ltd., the plaintiff, against ARG Outlier Media Pvt Ltd. and others, the defendants, seeking to place on record additional documents.

**Legal Issues:**
The legal issue in this case revolves around whether the plaintiff can file additional documents 18 months after the filing of the suit, particularly when some of the documents pertain to a defendant (defendant no. 1) who had already been deleted from the array of parties.

**Arguments:**

* **Plaintiff:** Counsel for the plaintiff argued that the additional documents were necessitated due to statements made by the defendants in their written statement and replies to examination reports filed with the Trade Mark Registry, which contradicted their stand taken in the present suit. The plaintiff also sought to place on record these documents to demonstrate that defendant no. 1 was in existence at the time of filing of the suit.
* **Defendants:** Senior counsel appearing for the defendants argued that since defendant no. 1 had already been deleted from the array of parties, the documents with regard to the defendant no. 1 are no longer relevant in the present suit. It was also contended that there is no contradiction in the stand taken by the defendants before the Trade Mark Registry and their written statement filed in the present suit.

**Court Findings:**

* The Court observed that a perusal of the additional documents sought to be placed on record by the plaintiff would show that they are examination reports of the Registry and responses thereto by the defendants.
* The Court noted that all the aforesaid documents pertain to the defendants, particularly defendant no. 2, who had taken a specific stand in their written statement that the trademark/taglines, which are the subject matter of the present suit are descriptive in nature.

**Decision:**

The Court rejected the plaintiff's application under Order XI Rule 5 of the CPC for placing on record additional documents. The Court held that:

* Since defendant no. 1 had already been deleted from the array of parties, the documents with regard to the defendant no. 1 are no longer relevant in the present suit.
* There is no contradiction in the stand taken by the defendants before the Trade Mark Registry and their written statement filed in the present suit.

The Court relied on the judgment of the Supreme Court in Sudhir Kumar v. Vinay Kumar (2021 SCC OnLine SC 734) and the judgment of a Co-ordinate Bench of this Court in Nitin Gupta v. Taxmaco Infrastructure & Holding Ltd. (2019 SCC OnLine Del 8367) to support its decision.

In light of these findings, the plaintiff's application was dismissed.

7. 
A perusal of the additional documents sought to be placed on record 
by the plaintiff would show that the said documents are the examination 
reports of the Registry and the responses thereto by the defendants. All the 
aforesaid documents pertain to the defendants. Attention of the Court has 
been drawn by the counsel for the plaintiff to paragraph 18 of the written 
statement filed by the defendant no.2, where a specific stand has been taken 
by the defendants that the trademark/taglines, which are the subject matter 
of the present suit are descriptive in nature. The aforesaid contention has 
been rebutted by the plaintiff in its replication. In order to meet the aforesaid 
contention of the defendants, the plaintiff seeks to place on record the 
aforesaid documents to show that in their replies to the examination reports, 
the defendants have claimed the trademark to be distinctive. The aforesaid 
documents are covered within the ambit of sub-rule (1)(c)(ii) of Rule (1) of 
Order XI of the CPC in terms of which the plaintiff would be entitled to file 
the documents in response to a case set up by the defendants after filing of 
the plaint. Therefore, there is no merit in the submission of the defendants 
that the aforesaid documents were available in public domain and could 
have been filed along with the plaint. Even if the said documents were 
available in public domain at the time of filing of the suit, the need for filing 
the aforesaid documents arose only on account of the stand taken by the 
defendants in the written statement.

**Background and Facts**

On March 6, 2023, the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi decided **CS(COMM) 434/2017**, a suit filed by Bennett Coleman & Co. Ltd. (Plaintiff) against ARG Outlier Media Pvt. Ltd. and others (Defendants).

**Key Points:**

* ARG Outlier Media Pvt. Ltd. & others (Defendants)

* Commencement of suit: Not specified

**Summary of Legal Document Section**

**Court:** High Court of Delhi at New Delhi
**Case Number:** CS(COMM) 434/2017
**Date of Decision:** March 6, 2023
**PDF Source:** Bennet Coleman & Co. Ltd vs. ARG Outlier Media Pvt. Ltd & Ors (18. pdf)

**Facts and Arguments:**

The plaintiff, Bennett Coleman & Co. Ltd., filed an application to add additional documents to the record of the case, alleging that they were not disclosed earlier due to discoverability. The defendants objected, citing Supreme Court judgments in Sudhir Kumar, Nitin Gupta, Hassad Food Company, and Mahesh Chaudhri.

**Decisions:**

The court allowed the plaintiff's application, relying on its own judgment in Khurmi Associates (P) Ltd. v. Maharishi Dayanand Co-Operative Group Housing Society (2022 SCC OnLine Del 1011). The court held that:

* Even if the documents were filed after the replication, they could still be added to the record if they support the pleadings and are relevant for the adjudication of the case.
* The fact that issues had not been framed in the suit and the additional documents were relevant for the determination of the case weighed in favor of allowing them to be added.

**Orders:**

The court permitted the plaintiff to add the additional documents to the record, subject to payment of costs of Rs. 20,000 to the defendants.

The court decision allowed the plaintiff to place additional documents on record, relying on previous judgments:

*   _Khurmi Associates (P) Ltd. v. Maharishi Dayanand Co-Operative Group Housing Society_ (2022 SCC OnLine Del 1011): similar facts, issues yet to be framed

Key points:

### Date of decision: March 6th, 2023

### Judgment in favor of:

nodes.content:

allowed to be taken on record on the ground that the issues were yet to be 
framed in the suit and additional documents sought to be filed by the 
plaintiff were relevant for the adjudication of the case.  
11. 
The judgments in Hassad Food Company (supra), Mahesh 
Chaudhri  (supra) and Nitin Gupta (supra) were considered by me in 
Khurmi Associates (P) Ltd. v. Maharishi Dayanand Co-Operative Group 
Housing Society, 2022 SCC OnLine Del 1011. Relying upon the judgments 
in Hassad Food Company (supra) and Mahesh Chaudhary (supra), the 
additional documents were permitted to be taken on record on the ground 
that issues were yet to be framed in the suit and the documents were in 
support of the pleadings of the plaintiff company.  
12. 
The facts in the present case are very similar to the facts in Khurmi 
Associates (supra). Issues are yet to be framed in the suit. It is an admitted 
position that the additional documents were filed on behalf of the plaintiff 
on the same date as the replication. A perusal of the pleadings in the suit 
would also show that the aforesaid documents sought to be filed are not 
contrary to the pleadings of the plaintiff in the suit. In my considered view, 
the aforesaid documents would be relevant for the adjudication of the 
present suit.  
13. 
Accordingly, the present application is allowed and the plaintiff is 
permitted to place the additional documents on record, subject to payment of 
costs of Rs.20,000/- to the defendants.
